facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 174 and 175 of 1967 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 174 and 175 of 1967. Appeals by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated June 16, 1966 of Mysore High Court in Ex. Regular Appeals Nos. 33-34 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 16, 1966 of the Mysore High Court in Ex. Regular Appeals Nos. 33-34 of 1961.

facts.text: High Court of Mysore passed common judgment on 16-6-1966 confirming District Court order allowing execution of compromise decree passed on 24-6-1959 in O.S. 85 of 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals, by special leave, are from the companymon judgment passed by High Court of Mysore on 16-6-1966 companyfirming the order of the District Court, Bangalore, allowing an application for execution of the companypromise decree passed on 24-6-1959 in appeal from the decree in O.S. 85 of 1949-50 of that companyrt.

facts.text: Appellant was the defendant and respondent the plaintiff in the suit O.S. 85 of 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the defendant in the suit and the respon- dent the plaintiff.

facts.text: Compromise decree provided defendant agrees to receive from plaintiff a lakh of rupees as consideration for sale of property No. 44, Mahatma Gandhi Road, Bangalore.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant agrees to receive from the plaintiff a lakh of rupees paid as companysideration for the sale of the property No. 44, Mahatma Gandhi Road, Bangalore, together with stamp charges of Rs. 3,300/-  rupees three thousand and three hundred only  with interest

facts.text: Compromise decree included stamp charges of Rs. 3,300 with interest at six per cent per annum from 16-3-1947.

anchor.surface_text: together with stamp charges of Rs. 3,300/-  rupees three thousand and three hundred only  with interest at six per cent per annum of the above two sums from 16-3-1947 up-to-date together with Rs. 7,000/-

facts.text: Compromise decree included Rs. 7,000 deducted by Corporation minus rent Rs. 22,500.

anchor.surface_text: from 16-3-1947 up-to-date together with Rs. 7,000/-  rupees seven thousand only  deducted by the Corporation minus the rent received viz., Rs. 22,500/-  rupees twenty two thousand and five hundred only  and give up all rights to the said property.

facts.text: Plaintiff entitled to materials lying on the premises under compromise decree.

anchor.surface_text: and give up all rights to the said property. The plaintiff will be entitled to the materials lying on the premises.

facts.text: Period fixed for payment by plaintiff to defendant till 1-1-1960 by depositing in court.

anchor.surface_text: The period of time fixed for the payment by the plaintiff to the defendant of this amount stated above is till 1-1-1960. The plaintiff agrees to deposit the amount in companyrt for payment to the defendant.

facts.text: On failure to deposit by 1-1-1960, suit in appeal dismissed with costs automatically; time essence of contract.

anchor.surface_text: On failure of the plaintiff to deposit the amount in companyrt by 1-1-1960 his suit number in appeal will be dismissed with companyts throughout. It is agreed by the parties that time is the essence of the companytract and numberfurther extension of time would be allowed and the dismissal of the suit with companyts would be automatic.

facts.text: Respondent applied for challan on 22-12-1959; challan issued on 24-12-1959, last working day before Christmas holidays.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent applied for challan on 22-12-1959 to deposit the amount and a challan was issued to him on 24-12-1959, the last working day before the companyrt closed for Christmas holidays.

facts.text: December 31, 1959 and January 1, 1960 were holidays; neither lower courts nor banks open.

anchor.surface_text: December 31, 1959 and January 1, 1960, were holidays. Neither the lower companyrts number the banks were open on these days.

facts.text: Respondent made deposit on 2-1-1960.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent made the deposit on 2-1-1960 and sought to enforce his right under the decree

facts.text: Respondent filed execution case No.25/1960 to compel appellant to execute conveyance.

anchor.surface_text: by companypelling the appellant to execute the companyveyance in terms of the companypromise decree by filing execution case No.25/1960.

facts.text: Appellant filed execution case No. 45 of 1960 claiming suit dismissed for failure to deposit by 1-1-1960.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also filed execution case No. 45 of 1960 for companyt on the basis that the suit stood dismissed as per the provision in the decree on the failure of the respondent to deposit the amount by 1-1-1960,

facts.text: District Court held deposit in substantial compliance, allowed execution case No.25/1960, dismissed No.45/1960.

anchor.surface_text: These two petitions were heard together, and the companyrt passed an order holding that the respondent had made the deposit in substantial companypliance with the decree and allowing execution case No. 25 of 1960 and dismissing execution case No. 45 of 1960.

facts.text: Appellant filed appeals 33 and 34 of 1960 before High Court of Mysore; dismissed by Division Bench on 16-6-1966 with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order, the appellant filed appeals 33 and 34 of 1960 before the High Court of Mysore. A Division Bench of the High Court, by its judgment dated 16-6-1966, dismissed the appeals with companyts.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds deposit on 2-1-1960 was within time specified in compromise decree due to holidays.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we think that the deposit made by the respondent on 2-1-1960 was in substance and in effect a deposit made in terms of the companypromise decree and that the High Court was right in its companyclusion.

facts.text: No evidence that parties knew December 31, 1959 and January 1, 1960 would be holidays at time of compromise.

anchor.surface_text: We may also state that there is numberevidence in this case that at the time when the companypromise was entered into, either of the parties knew that the 31st of December, 1959 and the 1st of January, 1960, would be holidays.

issues.text: whether the deposit made by the respondent on 2-1-1960 was within the time specified in the compromise decree and would enable him to compel the appellant to execute the sale deed in accordance with the provisions of the compromise decree

anchor.surface_text: The short question for companysideration in these appeals is whether the deposit made by the respondent on 2-1-1960 was within the time specified in the companypromise decree and would enable him to companypel the appellant to execute the sale deed in accordance with the provisions of the companypromise decree.

issues.text: what is the principle which should be applied in a case where a party to a consent decree is given time to do an act within a specified day or by a specified day and fails to do it on the ground of impossibility of performance on the last day specified but does it on the next practicable day

anchor.surface_text: The question then arises as to what is the principle which should be applied in a case where a party to a companysent decree is given time to do an act within a specified day or by a specified  lay and fails to do it on the ground of impossibility of performance on the last day specified but does it on the next practicable day.

holdings.text: The deposit made by the respondent on 2-1-1960 was in substance and in effect a deposit made in terms of the compromise decree

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we think that the deposit made by the respondent on 2-1-1960 was in substance and in effect a deposit made in terms of the companypromise decree and that the High Court was right in its conclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court closed on due date 1-1-1960 due to holidays; deposit on reopening day 2-1-1960 complies applying principle that parties entitled to perform on first subsequent opportunity when prevented by court closure

holdings.text: Generally recognised principle: parties prevented from doing act in court on particular day by court itself (not own act) entitled to do it at first subsequent opportunity

anchor.surface_text: there is a generally recognised principle of law under which parties who are prevented from doing a thing in companyrt on a particular day, not by an act of their own but by the companyrt itself, are entitled to do it at the first subsequent opportunity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle applies even where time fixed 'by' specified day in consent decree; no valid distinction from fixed day performance; supported by precedents like Muhammad Jan, Fateh Khan, Halsbury

holdings.text: Where decree specifically requires deposit in court, judgment-debtor has no option to pay directly to decree-holder under Order XXI Rule 1

anchor.surface_text: Although under Order XXI, Rule 1. it is open to a judgment debtor to pay the amount direct to the decree holder or to deposit in companyrt, he cannot choose the alternative when that will prejudice the decree holder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compromise decree mandates court deposit; direct payment would prejudice appellant; distinguishes Kunj Bihari etc. where option existed

holdings.text: Execution court cannot vary or modify decree terms but may construe decree in light of applicable law without varying it

anchor.surface_text: A companyrt executing the decree shall execute it as it stands. It cannot modify or vary the terms of the decree. No exception can be taken to that general principle. But the execution companyrt has the right to companystrue a decree in the light of the applicable provisions of law

holdings.reasoning_summary: Here, construing deposit effect under law of court closure does not vary decree but enforces as stands

anchor.surface_text: Although a companytract is number the less a companytract because it is embodied in a judges order... still we think it is something more than a companytract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consent decree has force of court order; cites Privy Council (Kinch), Bombay HC (Govind Waman), Morris v Barret distinguishing contract rules

precedents.citation: Fateh Khan and another v. Chhajju and others 1 , A.I.R. 1931 Lahore 386

anchor.surface_text: In Fateh Khan and another v. Chhajju and others 1 , an argument similar to the one addressed by counsel for the appellant was advanced but was not countenanced by the court. That was a case where a pre- emptor was unable to deposit the purchase money in court on the last day of the period allowed by the decree the period expired when the court was closed for the vacation and he deposited the amount on the reopening day.

precedents.cited_proposition: Deposit of purchase money on reopening day after court holiday on last day of period allowed by decree is valid; rejecting argument that party should have deposited earlier
precedents.cited_holding: The court repelled the argument by saying that if the argument is accepted it will have the effect of curtailing the days allowed to him by the decree without any reason.

precedents.citation: Kunj Bihari and others v. Bindeshri Prasad and others 1 , I.L.R. Vol. 51, 1929 Allahabad 527

anchor.surface_text: In support of this argument counsel referred to Kunj Bihari and others v. Bindeshri Prasad and others 1 , Roshan Lal v. Ganpat Lal 2 , Indal v. Chaudhary Ram Nidh 3 , and Ram Kinkar Singh and another v. Smt. Kamal Basini Devi 4 , Kunj Behari and others v. Bindeshri Prasad and others 1  was a case where an installment decree provided that the first installment was payable on a certain date the date specified expired during the vacation of the court

precedents.cited_proposition: When judgment debtor has option to pay direct to decree holder or deposit in court, cannot take advantage of court closure if could pay direct
precedents.cited_holding: depositing in court was not the only course open to them and so they could not take advantage of the fact that the court was closed on the specified date and the payment made by them was not made in time.

precedents.citation: Roshan Lal v. Ganpat Lal 2 , A.I.R. 1938 Allahabad 199

Bindeshri Prasad and others 1  was a case where an installment decree provided that the first installment was payable on a certain date the date specified expired during the vacation of the court

precedents.cited_proposition: Same principle as Kunj Bihari: no extension for court holiday if option to pay direct

precedents.case_name: Ram Kinkar Singh v. Smt. Kamal Basini Devi
precedents.cited_proposition: Same principle as Kunj Bihari regarding option to pay direct

precedents.citation: Chatlapali Suryaprakasa Rao v. Polisetti Venkataratnam and others 5 , A.I.R. 1938 Madras 523

anchor.surface_text: Even here there is a conflict of opinion among the High Courts. In Chatlapali Suryaprakasa Rao v. Polisetti Venkataratnam and others 5 , the compromise decree there in question provided that the decretal amount should be paid in certain yearly instalment on certain fixed date in each year.

precedents.case_name: Chatlapali Suryaprakasa Rao v. Polisetti Venkataratnam
precedents.cited_proposition: Judgment debtor did not commit default in payment of instalment due on holiday by paying next day
precedents.cited_holding: the judgment debtor did not commit default in payment of the second instalment and consequently there was no default of two successive instalments.

precedents.citation: Premchand Bhikabhai v. Ramdeo Sukdeo Marwadi 1 , A.I.R. 36 1949 Nagpur 141

anchor.surface_text: This is also the view that was taken in Premchand Bhikabhai v. Ramdeo Sukdeo Marwadi 1 . It is not necessary to resolve the conflict of opinion on this aspect as we are concerned with a decree which specifically provided that the respondent should deposit the amount in court.

precedents.case_name: Premchand Bhikabhai v. Ramdeo Sukdeo Marwadi
precedents.cited_proposition: Similar to Chatlapali: deposit next day valid when due on holiday

precedents.citation: Muhammad Jan v. Chiam Lal 2 , I.L.R. Allahabad Series, Vol. XLVI, 1924, p. 328

anchor.surface_text: The question then arises as to what is the principle which should be applied in a case where a party to a consent decree is given time to do an act within a specified day or by a specified lay and fails to do it on the ground of impossibility of performance on the last day specified but does it on the next practicable day. This question arose for consideration in Muhammad Jan v. Chiam Lal 2 .

precedents.cited_proposition: Deposit in pre-emption suit on reopening day after vacation is in time
precedents.cited_holding: there is a generally recognised principle of law under which parties who are prevented from doing a thing in court on a particular day, not by an act of their own but by the court itself, are entitled to do it at the first subsequent opportunity.

precedents.citation: Shooshee Bhusan Rudro and another v. Gobind Chunder Roy 3 , I.L.R. Calcutta, Vol. XVIII 1891 p. 231

anchor.surface_text: The court quoted with approval the decision in Shooshee Bhusan Rudro and another v. Gobind Chunder Roy 3  where it was observed that the broad principle is that although the parties themselves cannot extend the time for doing an act in court, yet if the delay is caused not by any act of their own, but by some act of the court itself-such as the fact of the court being closed-they are entitled to do the act on the first opening day.

precedents.case_name: Shooshee Bhusan Rudro v. Gobind Chunder Roy
precedents.cited_proposition: Parties entitled to do act on first opening day if court closed on due date
precedents.cited_holding: If the delay is caused not by any act of their own, but by some act of the court itself-such as the fact of the court being closed-they are entitled to do the act on the first opening day.

precedents.citation: Satnbasiva Chari v. Ramasami Reddi 1 , I.L.R. 22 Madras 1899 p. 179

anchor.surface_text: In Sambasiva Chari v. Ramasami Reddi 1 , the Madras High Court held that there is a generally recognised principle of law under which parties who are prevented from doing a thing in court on a particular day, not by any act of their own, but by the court itself, are entitled to do it at the first subsequent opportunity.

precedents.cited_proposition: Parties entitled to first subsequent opportunity if prevented by court closure
precedents.cited_holding: there is a generally recognised principle of law under which parties who are prevented from doing a thing in court on a particular day, not by any act of their own, but by the court itself, are entitled to do it at the first subsequent opportunity.

anchor.surface_text: We have already referred to Fateh Khan and another v. Chhajju and others where the Lahore High Court applied this principle to a pre- emption decree. Mayor v. Harding 2  is a case in point.

precedents.cited_proposition: Transmission of case within 3 days after receipt valid if done next practicable day after holidays
precedents.cited_holding: he had complied sufficiently with the requirement of the Act directing him to transmit the case within three days after receiving it, as it was impossible for him to transmit the case earlier than he did because of the closure of the offices of the court

anchor.surface_text: Although a contract is not the less a contract because it is embodied in a judges order, or, as said by Parke J. in Wentworth v. Bullen 1 B. C. 840, 850 the contract of the parties is not the less a contract, and subject to the incidents of a contract. because there is super-added the command of a judge.

precedents.cited_proposition: Contract embodied in judge's order is still subject to incidents of contract
precedents.cited_holding: the contract of the parties is not the less a contract, and subject to the incidents of a contract. because there is super-added the command of a judge.

precedents.citation: Charles Hubert Kinch v. Edward Keith Walcott and others 2 , A.I.R. 1929 journal Privy Council, P. 289

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Charles Hubert Kinch v. Edward Keith Walcott and others 2  observed An order by consent, not discharged by mutual agreement and remaining unreduced is as effective as an order of the court made otherwise than by consent and not discharged on appeal.

precedents.case_name: Charles Hubert Kinch v. Edward Keith Walcott
precedents.cited_proposition: Consent order as effective as regular court order unless discharged
precedents.cited_holding: A party bound by a consent order must when once it has been completed, obey it, unless and until he can get it set aside in proceedings duly constituted for the purpose.

precedents.citation: Govind Waman v. Murlidhar Shrinivas and others 3 , A.I.R. 1953 Bombay 412

anchor.surface_text: In Govind Waman v. Murlidhar Shrinivas and others 3 , the Bombay High Court held that a consent decree passed by a court of competent jurisdiction cannot be treated on the same footing as a contract between the parties,

precedents.cited_proposition: Consent decree more than mere contract; binding even if term contrary to law unless set aside
precedents.cited_holding: a consent decree passed by a court of competent jurisdiction cannot be treated on the same footing as a contract between the parties

precedents.citation: Morris v. Barret 1 , English Law Reports 141, p. 768

anchor.surface_text: That different consideration would apply when a contract is embodied in a judges order is also clear from Morris v. Barret 1 . In that case by a consent order it was provided that, upon payment of 341., the debt and costs as agreed, in installments on the 28th of May, on the 25th of June and on the 25th of every succeeding month until the whole is paid, all further proceedings in the cause be stayed.

precedents.cited_proposition: In consent order for installment payment due on Sunday, payment offered next day valid
precedents.cited_holding: the defendant had the whole of Monday to pay the money
